title: The least common multiple
content: According to Wikipedia ("Least common multiple", 27-Aug-2020, ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Least_common_multiple ): "In arithmetic and number theory, the _least common multiple_, lowest common multiple, or smallest common multiple of two integers a and b, usually denoted by lcm(a, b), is the smallest positive integer that is divisible by both a and b. Since division of integers by zero is undefined, this definition has meaning only if a and b are both different from zero. However, some authors define lcm(a,0) as 0 for all a, which is the result of taking the lcm to be the least upper bound in the lattice of divisibility. ... The lcm of more than two integers is also well-defined: it is the smallest positive integer hat is divisible by each of them." In this section, an operation calculating the least common multiple of two integers ( ~ df-lcm ) as well as a function mapping a set of integers to their least common multiple ( ~ df-lcmf ) are provided. Both definitions are valid for all integers, including negative integers and 0, obeying the above mentioned convention. It is shown by ~ lcmfpr that the two definitions are compatible.

blocks.name: lcmval
blocks.content: Value of the ` lcm ` operator. ` ( M lcm N ) ` is the least common multiple of ` M ` and ` N ` . If either ` M ` or ` N ` is ` 0 ` , the result is defined conventionally as ` 0 ` . Contrast with ~ df-gcd and ~ gcdval . (Contributed by Steve Rodriguez, 20-Jan-2020.) (Revised by AV, 16-Sep-2020.)

  ⊣ d(s0, c0)
  ⊣ d(s0, c1)
} = {
  ovmpt2(hs0, hs1, c0, cz, c1, cz, clcm, if((c0 = 0 ∨ c1 = 0), 0, inf({ s0 ∈ ℕ |(c0[||]s0 ∧ c1[||]s0)}, ℝ, <)), if((hs0 = 0 ∨ hs1 = 0), 0, inf({ s0 ∈ ℕ |(hs0[||]s0 ∧ hs1[||]s0)}, ℝ, <)), if((c0 = 0 ∨ hs1 = 0), 0, inf({ s0 ∈ ℕ |(c0[||]s0 ∧ hs1[||]s0)}, ℝ, <)))
  ifbieq2d(nat0, inf({ s0 ∈ ℕ |(hs0[||]s0 ∧ hs1[||]s0)}, ℝ, <), inf({ s0 ∈ ℕ |(c0[||]s0 ∧ hs1[||]s0)}, ℝ, <), hs0 = c0, (hs0 = 0 ∨ hs1 = 0), (c0 = 0 ∨ hs1 = 0))
  orbi1d(hs0 = c0, hs0 = 0, hs1 = 0, c0 = 0)
  eqeq1(hs0, c0, nat0)
  infeq1d({ s0 ∈ ℕ |(hs0[||]s0 ∧ hs1[||]s0)}, cr, clt, { s0 ∈ ℕ |(c0[||]s0 ∧ hs1[||]s0)}, hs0 = c0)
  rabbidv(s0, cn, hs0 = c0, (hs0[||]s0 ∧ hs1[||]s0), (c0[||]s0 ∧ hs1[||]s0))
  anbi1d(hs0 = c0, hs0[||]s0, hs1[||]s0, c0[||]s0)
  breq1(hs0, c0, cdvds, s0)
  ifbieq2d(nat0, inf({ s0 ∈ ℕ |(c0[||]s0 ∧ hs1[||]s0)}, ℝ, <), inf({ s0 ∈ ℕ |(c0[||]s0 ∧ c1[||]s0)}, ℝ, <), hs1 = c1, (c0 = 0 ∨ hs1 = 0), (c0 = 0 ∨ c1 = 0))
  orbi2d(hs1 = c1, c0 = 0, hs1 = 0, c1 = 0)
  eqeq1(hs1, c1, nat0)
  infeq1d({ s0 ∈ ℕ |(c0[||]s0 ∧ hs1[||]s0)}, cr, clt, { s0 ∈ ℕ |(c0[||]s0 ∧ c1[||]s0)}, hs1 = c1)
  rabbidv(s0, cn, hs1 = c1, (c0[||]s0 ∧ hs1[||]s0), (c0[||]s0 ∧ c1[||]s0))
  anbi2d(hs1 = c1, c0[||]s0, hs1[||]s0, c1[||]s0)
  breq1(hs1, c1, cdvds, s0)
  df-lcm(hs0, hs1, s0)
  ifex(nat0, inf({ s0 ∈ ℕ |(c0[||]s0 ∧ c1[||]s0)}, ℝ, <), (c0 = 0 ∨ c1 = 0))
  c0ex()
  infex({ s0 ∈ ℕ |(c0[||]s0 ∧ c1[||]s0)}, cr, clt)
  ltso()
  diff.hs0.s(hs1)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(cz)
  diff.hs0.c(c1)
  diff.hs0.c(if((c0 = 0 ∨ c1 = 0), 0, inf({ s0 ∈ ℕ |(c0[||]s0 ∧ c1[||]s0)}, ℝ, <)))
  diff.hs1.c(c0)

  diff.hs1.c(c1)
  diff.hs1.c(if((c0 = 0 ∨ c1 = 0), 0, inf({ s0 ∈ ℕ |(c0[||]s0 ∧ c1[||]s0)}, ℝ, <)))
  diff.wceq.s(s0, hs0, c0)
  diff.cv.s(s0, hs0)

blocks.name: lcmcom
blocks.content: The ` lcm ` operator is commutative. (Contributed by Steve Rodriguez, 20-Jan-2020.) (Proof shortened by AV, 16-Sep-2020.)
blocks.origin:
thm lcmcom(class c0, class c1) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz)), wceq(co(c0, clcm, c1), co(c1, clcm, c0)))
} = {
  3eqtr4a(co(c0, clcm, c1), co(c1, clcm, c0), cif(nat0, cinf(crab(hs0, cn, wa(wbr(c0, cdvds, cv(hs0)), wbr(c1, cdvds, cv(hs0)))), cr, clt), wo(wceq(c0, nat0), wceq(c1, nat0))), cif(nat0, cinf(crab(hs0, cn, wa(wbr(c1, cdvds, cv(hs0)), wbr(c0, cdvds, cv(hs0)))), cr, clt), wo(wceq(c1, nat0), wceq(c0, nat0))), wa(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz)))
  ifbieq2i(nat0, cinf(crab(hs0, cn, wa(wbr(c0, cdvds, cv(hs0)), wbr(c1, cdvds, cv(hs0)))), cr, clt), cinf(crab(hs0, cn, wa(wbr(c1, cdvds, cv(hs0)), wbr(c0, cdvds, cv(hs0)))), cr, clt), wo(wceq(c0, nat0), wceq(c1, nat0)), wo(wceq(c1, nat0), wceq(c0, nat0)))
  orcom(wceq(c0, nat0), wceq(c1, nat0))
  infeq1i(crab(hs0, cn, wa(wbr(c0, cdvds, cv(hs0)), wbr(c1, cdvds, cv(hs0)))), cr, clt, crab(hs0, cn, wa(wbr(c1, cdvds, cv(hs0)), wbr(c0, cdvds, cv(hs0)))))
  rabbii(hs0, cn, wa(wbr(c0, cdvds, cv(hs0)), wbr(c1, cdvds, cv(hs0))), wa(wbr(c1, cdvds, cv(hs0)), wbr(c0, cdvds, cv(hs0))))
  ancom(wbr(c0, cdvds, cv(hs0)), wbr(c1, cdvds, cv(hs0)))
  lcmval(hs0, c0, c1)
  ancoms(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz), wceq(co(c1, clcm, c0), cif(nat0, cinf(crab(hs0, cn, wa(wbr(c1, cdvds, cv(hs0)), wbr(c0, cdvds, cv(hs0)))), cr, clt), wo(wceq(c1, nat0), wceq(c0, nat0)))))
  lcmval(hs0, c1, c0)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(c1)
}

blocks.name: lcm0val
blocks.content: The value, by convention, of the ` lcm ` operator when either operand is 0. (Use ~ lcmcom for a left-hand 0.) (Contributed by Steve Rodriguez, 20-Jan-2020.) (Proof shortened by AV, 16-Sep-2020.)

blocks.name: lcmn0val
blocks.content: The value of the ` lcm ` operator when both operands are nonzero. (Contributed by Steve Rodriguez, 20-Jan-2020.) (Revised by AV, 16-Sep-2020.)

  sylan9eqr(co(c0, clcm, c1), nat0, co(nat0, clcm, c1), wcel(c1, cz), wceq(c0, nat0))

blocks.name: lcmgcd
blocks.content: The product of two numbers' least common multiple and greatest common divisor is the absolute value of the product of the two numbers. In particular, that absolute value _is_ the least common multiple of two coprime numbers, for which ` ( M gcd N ) = 1 ` . Multiple methods exist for proving this, and it is often proven either as a consequence of the fundamental theorem of arithmetic ~ 1arith or of Bézout's identity ~ bezout ; see e.g., ~ https://proofwiki.org/wiki/Product_of_GCD_and_LCM and ~ https://math.stackexchange.com/a/470827 . This proof uses the latter to first confirm it for positive integers ` M ` and ` N ` (the "Second Proof" in the above Stack Exchange page), then shows that implies it for all nonzero integer inputs, then finally uses ~ lcm0val to show it applies when either or both inputs are zero. (Contributed by Steve Rodriguez, 20-Jan-2020.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: lcmdvds
blocks.content: The lcm of two integers divides any integer the two divide. (Contributed by Steve Rodriguez, 20-Jan-2020.)

  3eqtr3d(co(co(c0, clcm, c0), cmul, cfv(cabs, c0)), co(cfv(cabs, c0), cmul, cfv(cabs, c0)), co(co(c0, clcm, c0), cmul, co(c0, cgcd, c0)), cfv(cabs, co(c0, cmul, c0)), wcel(c0, cz))

blocks.name: lcmgcdnn
blocks.content: The product of two positive integers' least common multiple and greatest common divisor is the product of the two integers. (Contributed by AV, 27-Aug-2020.)

  nnz(c1)

  nnmulcl(c0, c1)
  jca(wcel(co(c0, cmul, c1), cn0), wcel(co(c0, cmul, c1), cr), wbr(nat0, cle, co(c0, cmul, c1)))

blocks.name: lcmgcdeq

thm lcmgcdeq(class c0, class c1) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz)), wb(wceq(co(c0, clcm, c1), co(c0, cgcd, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, c0), cfv(cabs, c1))))
} = {
  impbida(wa(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz)), wceq(co(c0, clcm, c1), co(c0, cgcd, c1)), wceq(cfv(cabs, c0), cfv(cabs, c1)))
  mp2and(wa(wa(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz)), wceq(co(c0, clcm, c1), co(c0, cgcd, c1))), wceq(cfv(cabs, c0), cfv(cabs, c1)), wbr(cfv(cabs, c0), cdvds, cfv(cabs, c1)), wbr(cfv(cabs, c1), cdvds, cfv(cabs, c0)))
  mpbid(wa(wa(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz)), wceq(co(c0, clcm, c1), co(c0, cgcd, c1))), wbr(cfv(cabs, c0), cdvds, cfv(cabs, c1)), wbr(c0, cdvds, c1))
  mp2and(wa(wa(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz)), wceq(co(c0, clcm, c1), co(c0, cgcd, c1))), wbr(c0, cdvds, c1), wbr(c0, cdvds, co(c0, clcm, c1)), wbr(co(c0, clcm, c1), cdvds, c1))
  adantr(wa(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz)), wceq(co(c0, clcm, c1), co(c0, cgcd, c1)), wbr(c0, cdvds, co(c0, clcm, c1)))
  simpld(wa(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz)), wbr(c0, cdvds, co(c0, clcm, c1)), wbr(c1, cdvds, co(c0, clcm, c1)))
  imp(wa(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz)), wceq(co(c0, clcm, c1), co(c0, cgcd, c1)), wbr(co(c0, clcm, c1), cdvds, c1))
  syl5ibrcom(wa(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz)), wceq(co(c0, clcm, c1), co(c0, cgcd, c1)), wbr(co(c0, clcm, c1), cdvds, c1), wbr(co(c0, cgcd, c1), cdvds, c1))
  simprd(wa(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz)), wbr(co(c0, cgcd, c1), cdvds, c1), wbr(co(c0, cgcd, c1), cdvds, c0))
  breq1(co(c0, clcm, c1), co(c0, cgcd, c1), cdvds, c1)
  adantr(wa(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz)), wceq(co(c0, clcm, c1), co(c0, cgcd, c1)), wi(wa(wbr(c0, cdvds, co(c0, clcm, c1)), wbr(co(c0, clcm, c1), cdvds, c1)), wbr(c0, cdvds, c1)))

thm lcmdvdsb(class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wi(w3a(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz), wcel(c2, cz)), wb(wa(wbr(c1, cdvds, c0), wbr(c2, cdvds, c0)), wbr(co(c1, clcm, c2), cdvds, c0)))
} = {
  impbid(w3a(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz), wcel(c2, cz)), wa(wbr(c1, cdvds, c0), wbr(c2, cdvds, c0)), wbr(co(c1, clcm, c2), cdvds, c0))
  lcmdvds(c0, c1, c2)
  jcad(w3a(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz), wcel(c2, cz)), wbr(co(c1, clcm, c2), cdvds, c0), wbr(c1, cdvds, c0), wbr(c2, cdvds, c0))
  mpand(w3a(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz), wcel(c2, cz)), wbr(co(c1, clcm, c2), cdvds, c0), wbr(c1, cdvds, c0), wbr(c1, cdvds, co(c1, clcm, c2)))

thm lcmdvdsb(class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  ⊢ ((c0 ∈ ℤ ∧ c1 ∈ ℤ ∧ c2 ∈ ℤ)→((c1[||]c0 ∧ c2[||]c0)↔(c1[lcm]c2)[||]c0))
} = {
  impbid((c0 ∈ ℤ ∧ c1 ∈ ℤ ∧ c2 ∈ ℤ), (c1[||]c0 ∧ c2[||]c0), (c1[lcm]c2)[||]c0)

  jcad((c0 ∈ ℤ ∧ c1 ∈ ℤ ∧ c2 ∈ ℤ), (c1[lcm]c2)[||]c0, c1[||]c0, c2[||]c0)
  mpand((c0 ∈ ℤ ∧ c1 ∈ ℤ ∧ c2 ∈ ℤ), (c1[lcm]c2)[||]c0, c1[||]c0, c1[||](c1[lcm]c2))

  simpld((c1 ∈ ℤ ∧ c2 ∈ ℤ), c1[||](c1[lcm]c2), c2[||](c1[lcm]c2))

  simp2(c0 ∈ ℤ, c1 ∈ ℤ, c2 ∈ ℤ)
  simp1(c0 ∈ ℤ, c1 ∈ ℤ, c2 ∈ ℤ)
  dvdstr(c1, (c1[lcm]c2), c0)
  mpand((c0 ∈ ℤ ∧ c1 ∈ ℤ ∧ c2 ∈ ℤ), (c1[lcm]c2)[||]c0, c2[||]c0, c2[||](c1[lcm]c2))

blocks.name: 3lcm2e6woprm
blocks.content: The least common multiple of three and two is six. In contrast to ~ 3lcm2e6 , this proof does not use the property of 2 and 3 being prime, therefore it is much longer. (Contributed by Steve Rodriguez, 20-Jan-2020.) (Revised by AV, 27-Aug-2020.) (Proof modification is discouraged.) (New usage is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: lcmfval
blocks.content: Value of the ` _lcm ` function. ` ( _lcm `` Z ) ` is the least common multiple of the integers contained in the finite subset of integers ` Z ` . If at least one of the elements of ` Z ` is ` 0 ` , the result is defined conventionally as ` 0 ` . (Contributed by AV, 21-Apr-2020.) (Revised by AV, 16-Sep-2020.)

  rabbidv(hs1, cn, (c0 ∈ ℤ ∧ c1 ∈ ℤ), ∀(hs0 ∈ { c0, c1 }, hs0[||]hs1), (c0[||]hs1 ∧ c1[||]hs1))
  ralprg(hs0, c0, cz, c1, cz, hs0[||]hs1, c0[||]hs1, c1[||]hs1)

blocks.name: lcmfledvds
blocks.content: A positive integer which is divisible by all elements of a set of integers bounds the least common multiple of the set. (Contributed by AV, 22-Aug-2020.) (Proof shortened by AV, 16-Sep-2020.)

  sylancr(wa(wss(c0, cz), wa(wcel(c1, cn), wral(s0, c0, wbr(cv(s0), cdvds, c1)))), wbr(cinf(crab(hs0, cn, wral(s0, c0, wbr(cv(s0), cdvds, cv(hs0)))), cr, clt), cle, c1), wss(crab(hs0, cn, wral(s0, c0, wbr(cv(s0), cdvds, cv(hs0)))), cfv(cuz, nat1)), wcel(c1, crab(hs0, cn, wral(s0, c0, wbr(cv(s0), cdvds, cv(hs0))))))

blocks.name: lcmf
blocks.content: Characterization of the least common multiple of a set of integers (without 0): A positiven integer is the least common multiple of a set of integers iff it divides each of the elements of the set and every integer which divides each of the elements of the set is greater than or equal to this integer. (Contributed by AV, 22-Aug-2020.)

blocks.name: lcmf0
blocks.content: The least common multiple of the empty set is 1. (Contributed by AV, 22-Aug-2020.) (Proof shortened by AV, 16-Sep-2020.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: lcmfsn
blocks.content: The least common multiple of a singleton is its absolute value. (Contributed by AV, 22-Aug-2020.)

blocks.name: lcmftp
blocks.content: The least common multiple of a triple of integers is the least common multiple of the third integer and the least common multiple of the first two integers. Although there would be a shorter proof using ~ lcmfunsn , this explicit proof (not based on induction) should be kept. (Proof modification is discouraged.) (Contributed by AV, 23-Aug-2020.)

blocks.name: lcmfunsnlem
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ lcmfdvds and ~ lcmfunsn . These two theorems must be proven simultaneously by induction on the cardinality of a finite set ` Y ` , because they depend on each other. This can be seen by the two parts ~ lcmfunsnlem1 and ~ lcmfunsnlem2 of the induction step, each of them using both induction hypotheses. (Contributed by AV, 26-Aug-2020.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: lcmfdvds
blocks.content: The least common multiple of a set of integers divides any integer which is divisible by all elements of the set. (Contributed by AV, 26-Aug-2020.)
blocks.origin:

  |- wi(w3a(wcel(c0, cz), wss(c1, cz), wcel(c1, cfn)), wi(wral(s0, c1, wbr(cv(s0), cdvds, c0)), wbr(cfv(clcmf, c1), cdvds, c0)))
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
} = {
  3impib(wcel(c0, cz), wss(c1, cz), wcel(c1, cfn), wi(wral(s0, c1, wbr(cv(s0), cdvds, c0)), wbr(cfv(clcmf, c1), cdvds, c0)))

  adantr(wral(hs0, cz, wi(wral(s0, c1, wbr(cv(s0), cdvds, cv(hs0))), wbr(cfv(clcmf, c1), cdvds, cv(hs0)))), wral(hs1, cz, wceq(cfv(clcmf, cun(c1, csn(cv(hs1)))), co(cfv(clcmf, c1), clcm, cv(hs1)))), wi(wcel(c0, cz), wi(wral(s0, c1, wbr(cv(s0), cdvds, c0)), wbr(cfv(clcmf, c1), cdvds, c0))))
  rspccv(hs0, cz, c0, wi(wral(s0, c1, wbr(cv(s0), cdvds, cv(hs0))), wbr(cfv(clcmf, c1), cdvds, cv(hs0))), wi(wral(s0, c1, wbr(cv(s0), cdvds, c0)), wbr(cfv(clcmf, c1), cdvds, c0)))
  imbi12d(wceq(cv(hs0), c0), wral(s0, c1, wbr(cv(s0), cdvds, cv(hs0))), wbr(cfv(clcmf, c1), cdvds, cv(hs0)), wral(s0, c1, wbr(cv(s0), cdvds, c0)), wbr(cfv(clcmf, c1), cdvds, c0))
  ralbidv(s0, c1, wceq(cv(hs0), c0), wbr(cv(s0), cdvds, cv(hs0)), wbr(cv(s0), cdvds, c0))
  breq2(cv(hs0), c0, cv(s0), cdvds)

  jctir((c0 ⊆ ℤ ∧ c0 ∈ Fin), {(_lcm ` c0)} ⊆ ℤ, {(_lcm ` c0)} ∈ Fin)
  snssd((_lcm ` c0), cz, (c0 ⊆ ℤ ∧ c0 ∈ Fin))
